As an AI language model, I do not have access to the current visual information. However, I can provide some general guidance for visually impaired individuals to navigate grocery stores.

1. Ask for assistance: Many grocery stores have staff who are trained to assist customers with visual impairments. You can ask for assistance at the store's customer service desk or the entrance.

2. Use a white cane: A white cane can be a helpful tool for visually impaired individuals to navigate through grocery stores. You can hold the cane in your dominant hand and use it to guide your way.

3. Use your other senses: You can use your sense of hearing to your advantage. Listen for announcements about sales, special deals, or new products. You can also use your sense of smell to identify fresh produce or other items.

4. Familiarize yourself with the layout: Before you go grocery shopping, take some time to familiarize yourself with the layout of the store. This will help you know where to go to find the items you need.

5. Use labels and signs: Many grocery stores have labels and signs that provide information about the products. Use these labels and signs to your advantage to locate the items you need.

Remember, it may take some time to get used to navigating grocery stores with visual impairments. Be patient and persistent, and don't be afraid to ask for help when you need it.

When navigating a grocery store, it's important to have a clear idea of what you need to buy and to plan your route ahead of time. You can use a map of the store or create a list of items you need to purchase. It's also helpful to use a white cane or guide dog to help you navigate the store.
